neurocaps.extraction.TimeseriesExtractorÔÉÅ

class neurocaps.extraction.TimeseriesExtractor(space: str = 'MNI152NLin2009cAsym', standardize: bool | str = 'zscore_sample', detrend: bool = True, low_pass: float | None = None, high_pass: float | None = None, parcel_approach: Dict[str, Dict] = {'Schaefer': {'n_rois': 400, 'resolution_mm': 1, 'yeo_networks': 7}}, use_confounds: bool = True, confound_names: List[str] | None = None, fwhm: float | None = None, fd_threshold: float | None = None, n_acompcor_separate: int | None = None, dummy_scans: int | None = None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Timeseries Extractor Class

Initializes the TimeseriesExtractor class.

Parameters:

  • space (str, default="MNI152NLin2009cAsym") ‚Äì The standard template space that the preprocessed bold data is registered to.

  • standardize (bool or str, default="zscore_sample") ‚Äì Determines whether to standardize the timeseries. Refer to Nilearn‚Äôs NiftiLabelsMasker for available options.

  • detrend (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Detrends the timeseries during extraction.

  • low_pass (float or None, default=None) ‚Äì Filters out signals above the specified cutoff frequency.

  • high_pass (float or None, default=None) ‚Äì Filters out signals below the specified cutoff frequency.

  • parcel_approach (Dict[str, Dict], default={"Schaefer": {"n_rois": 400, "yeo_networks": 7, "resolution_mm": 1}}) ‚Äì

    The approach to parcellate BOLD images. This should be a nested dictionary with the first key being the atlas name. Currently, only ‚ÄúSchaefer‚Äù, ‚ÄúAAL‚Äù, and ‚ÄúCustom‚Äù are supported.

    • For ‚ÄúSchaefer‚Äù, available options include n_rois, yeo_networks, and resolution_mm. Refer to Nilearn‚Äôs datasets.fetch_atlas_schaefer_2018 for valid inputs.

    • For ‚ÄúAAL‚Äù, the only option is version. Refer to Nilearn‚Äôs datasets.fetch_atlas_aal for valid inputs.

    • For ‚ÄúCustom‚Äù, the key must include a subkey called maps specifying the directory location of the parcellation Nifti file (e.g., {‚ÄúCustom‚Äù: {‚Äúmaps‚Äù: ‚Äú/location/to/parcellation.nii.gz‚Äù}}).

  • use_confounds (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Determines whether to use confounds when extracting timeseries.

  • confound_names (List[str] or None, default=None) ‚Äì Specifies the names of confounds to use from confound files. If None, default confounds are used. Note, an asterisk (‚Äú*‚Äù) can be used to find confound names that start with the term preceding the asterisk. For instance, ‚Äúcosine*‚Äù will find all confound names in the confound files starting with ‚Äúcosine‚Äù.

  • fwhm (float or None, default=None) ‚Äì Applies spatial smoothing to data (in millimeters). Note that using parcellations already averages voxels within parcel boundaries, which can improve signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) assuming Gaussian noise distribution. However, smoothing may also blur parcel boundaries.

  • fd_threshold (float or None, default=None) ‚Äì Sets a threshold to remove frames after nuisance regression and timeseries extraction. This requires a column named framewise_displacement in the confounds dataframe and use_confounds set to True. Additionally, framewise_displacement should not need be specified in confound_names if using this parameter.

  • n_acompcor_separate (int or None, default=None) ‚Äì Specifies the number of separate acompcor components derived from white-matter (WM) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) masks to use. For example, if set to 5, the first five components from the WM mask and the first five from the CSF mask will be used, totaling ten acompcor components. If this parameter is not None, any acompcor components listed in confound_names will be disregarded. To use acompcor components derived from combined masks (WM & CSF), leave this parameter as None and list the specific acompcors of interest in confound_names.

  • dummy_scans (int or None, default=None) ‚Äì Removes the first n volumes before extracting the timeseries.

Notes for confounds_namesÔÉÅ

Additionally, default confound_names changes if high_pass is not None.

If high_pass is not None, then the cosine parameters and acompcor parameters are not used because the cosine parameters are high-pass filters and the acompcor regressors are estimated on the high-pass filtered version of the data:

confound_names = ["trans_x", "trans_x_derivative1","trans_y", "trans_y_derivative1",
                  "trans_z", "trans_z_derivative1",  "rot_x", "rot_x_derivative1",
                  "rot_y", "rot_y_derivative1", "rot_z", "rot_z_derivative1"]

If high_pass is None, then:

confound_names = ["trans_x", "trans_x_derivative1","trans_y", "trans_y_derivative1",
                  "trans_z", "trans_z_derivative1",  "rot_x", "rot_x_derivative1",
                  "rot_y", "rot_y_derivative1", "rot_z", "rot_z_derivative1"]

else:

confound_names = ["cosine*","trans_x", "trans_x_derivative1","trans_y", "trans_y_derivative1",
                  "trans_z", "trans_z_derivative1",  "rot_x", "rot_x_derivative1",
                  "rot_y", "rot_y_derivative1", "rot_z", "rot_z_derivative1", "a_comp_cor_00",
                  "a_comp_cor_01", "a_comp_cor_02", "a_comp_cor_03", "a_comp_cor_04", "a_comp_cor_05"]

Notes for parcel_approachÔÉÅ

If using a ‚ÄúCustom‚Äù parcellation approach, ensure each node in your dataset includes both left (lh) and right (rh) hemisphere versions. This function assumes that the background label is ‚Äúzero‚Äù. Do not add a background label in the ‚Äúnodes‚Äù or ‚Äúnetworks‚Äù key; the zero index should correspond to the first ID that is not zero.

Custom Key Structure:ÔÉÅ

  • ‚Äòmaps‚Äô: Directory path containing necessary parcellation files. Ensure files are in a supported format (e.g., .nii for NIfTI files). For plotting purposes, this key is not required.

  • ‚Äònodes‚Äô: List of all node labels used in your study, arranged in the exact order they correspond to indices in your parcellation files. Each label should match the parcellation index it represents. For example, if the parcellation label ‚Äú1‚Äù corresponds to the left hemisphere visual cortex area 1, then ‚ÄúLH_Vis1‚Äù should occupy the 0th index in this list. This ensures that data extraction and analysis accurately reflect the anatomical regions intended. For timeseries extraction, this key is not required.

  • ‚Äòregions‚Äô: Dictionary defining major brain regions. Each region should list node indices under ‚Äúlh‚Äù and ‚Äúrh‚Äù to specify left and right hemisphere nodes. For timeseries extraction, this key is not required.

Example

The provided example demonstrates setting up a custom parcellation containing nodes for the visual network (Vis) and hippocampus regions:

parcel_approach = {"Custom": {"maps": "/location/to/parcellation.nii.gz",
                     "nodes": ["LH_Vis1", "LH_Vis2", "LH_Hippocampus", "RH_Vis1", "RH_Vis2", "RH_Hippocampus"],
                     "regions": {"Vis" : {"lh": [0,1],
                                          "rh": [3,4]},
                                 "Hippocampus": {"lh": [2],
                                                 "rh": [5]}}}}
get_bold(bids_dir: Path, task: str, session: int | str | None = None, runs: List[int] | None = None, condition: str | None = None, tr: int | float | None = None, run_subjects: List[str] | None = None, exclude_subjects: List[str] | None = None, pipeline_name: str | None = None, n_cores: int | None = None, verbose: bool = True, flush_print: bool = False, exclude_niftis: List[str] | None = None) → None[source]ÔÉÅ

Get Bold Data

Collects files needed to extract timeseries data from NIfTI files for BIDS-compliant datasets containing a derivatives folder. This function assumes that your BOLD data was preprocessed using a standard preprocessing pipeline such as fMRIPrep.

Parameters:

  • bids_dir (Path) ‚Äì Path to a BIDS compliant directory.

  • task (str) ‚Äì Name of task to process.

  • session (int or None, default=None) ‚Äì Session to extract timeseries from. Only a single session can be extracted at a time.

  • runs (List[int], default=None) ‚Äì

    List of run numbers to extract timeseries data from. Extracts all runs if unspecified. For instance, if only ‚Äúrun-0‚Äù and ‚Äúrun-1‚Äù should be extracted, then:

    runs=[0,1]

  • condition (str or None, default=None) ‚Äì Specific condition in the task to extract from. Only a single condition can be extracted at a time.

  • tr (int or float or None, default=None) ‚Äì Repetition time for task.

  • run_subjects (List[str] or None, default=None) ‚Äì List of subject IDs to process. Processes all subjects if None.

  • exclude_subjects (List[str] or None, default=None) ‚Äì List of subject IDs to exclude.

  • pipeline_name (str or None, default=None) ‚Äì The name of the pipeline folder in the derivatives folder containing the preprocessed data. If None, BIDSLayout will use the name of dset_dir with derivatives=True. This parameter should be used if there are multiple pipelines in the derivatives folder.

  • n_cores (int or None, default=None) ‚Äì The number of CPU cores to use for multiprocessing with joblib.

  • verbose (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Print subject-specific information such as confounds being extracted, and id and run of subject being processed during timeseries extraction.

  • flush_print (bool, default=False) ‚Äì Flush the printed subject-specific infomation produced during the timeseries extraction process.

  • exclude_niftis (List[str] or None, default=None) ‚Äì List of specific preprocessed NIfTI files to exclude, preventing their timeseries from being extracted. Used if there are specific runs across differnt participants that need to be excluded.

Note

This function stores the extracted timeseries as a nested dictionary and stores it in self.subject_timeseres. The first level of the nested dictionary consists of the subject ID as a string, the second level consists of the run numbers in the form of ‚Äòrun-#‚Äô (where # is the corresponding number of the run), and the last level must consist of the timeseries (as a numpy array) associated with that run.

Additionally, if your files do not specify a run number due to your subjects only having a single run, the run id key for the second level of the nested dictionary defaults to ‚Äúrun-0‚Äù.

This function cannot be used on Windows PCs.

timeseries_to_pickle(output_dir: Path, file_name: str | None = None) → None[source]ÔÉÅ

Save Bold Data

Saves the timeseries dictionary obtained from running get_bold() as a pickle file.

Parameters:

  • output_dir (Path) ‚Äì Directory to save to. The directory will be created if it does not exist.

  • file_name (str or None, default=None) ‚Äì Name of the file with or without the ‚Äúpkl‚Äù extension.

visualize_bold(subj_id: int | str, run: int, roi_indx: int | List[int] | None = None, region: str | None = None, show_figs: bool = True, output_dir: Path | None = None, file_name: str | None = None, **kwargs) → None[source]ÔÉÅ

Plot Bold Data

Collects files needed to extract timeseries data from NIfTI files for BIDS-compliant datasets.

Parameters:

  • subj_id (str pr int) ‚Äì The subject ID.

  • run (int) ‚Äì The run to plot.

  • roi_indx (int or List[int] or None, default=None) ‚Äì The indices of the parcellation nodes to plot. See self.node_indices for valid node names and indices.

  • region (str or None, default=None) ‚Äì The region of the parcellation to plot. If not None, all nodes in the specified region will be averaged then plotted. See ‚Äúregions‚Äù in self.parcel_approach. for valid regions names.

  • show_figs (bool, default=True) ‚Äì Whether to show the figures.

  • output_dir (Path or None, default=None) ‚Äì Directory to save to. The directory will be created if it does not exist.

  • file_name (str or None, default=None) ‚Äì Name of the file without the extension.

  • **kwargs (Dict) ‚Äì

    Keyword arguments used when saving figures. Valid keywords include:

    • ‚Äùdpi‚Äù: int, default=300

      Dots per inch for the figure. Default is 300 if output_dir is provided and dpi is not specified.

    • ‚Äùfigsize‚Äù: tuple, default=(11, 5)

      Size of the figure in inches. Default is (11, 5) if figsize is not specified.

Returns:

matplotlib.Figure ‚Äì An instance of a matplotlib figure.
